title: Australian dollar pounded as QE speculation mounts
text:
"The reference to full employment was a bit more aggressive," agreed Sean Callow, senior currency strategist at Westpac. "The Reserve Bank does not want to do anything to encourage any thinking that easing is over."

After the central bank cut the cash rate in June and July, sentiment towards the Australian dollar was unmoved.

On Tuesday, the currency advanced immediately after the rate cut, even though the statement was strongly dovish in tone.

"We had an interesting spike at the start," said Mr Callow. "There was a little bit of optimism over Lowe's reference to a turning point before [the market settled on] deciding that was likely a backward-looking comment."

The central bank held back from any explicit reference to the level of the currency in its statement, but strategists say the exchange rate is bound to be a priority when the Reserve Bank considers the path of policy.

"The RBA sees the exchange rate as the transmission mechanism for monetary policy to the economy," said Mr Attrill. "In the past, they have said that a further easing in the dollar would be desirable."

Advertisement

Focusing on the exchange rate is not without drawbacks; other central banks are also cutting interest rates, including the US Federal Reserve.

Market expectations for another rate cut from the Fed rose overnight after dire figures from the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) survey, noted Mr Callow. That showed a drop in the US manufacturing gauge to 2009 levels.

"The ISM was a disaster. There's negativity around the US economy and a stronger case for the Fed to cut in October," Mr Callow said.

With heightened expectations for Fed easing, the Australian central bank "does not want to be the odd one out on interest rates," asserted Mr Callow. The Australian dollar recovered to US67.1¢ against the US dollar on Wednesday.

Other options

But as interest rates head to zero, the Reserve Bank will need to consider other options to support the economy. Any unconventional measures will probably focus on bond-buying, said Mr Attrill. "It depends on what amount of outstanding stock they have to buy."

That should in turn depress the currency, said Mr Callow. "By buying bonds you are flattening the yield curve and lower yields should make your currency less attractive.

"Theoretically, money is being created so the supply of Australian dollars increases. All other things being equal, increased supply means the price should fall."

Advertisement

When the US was at the height of QE, the Australian dollar was above parity with the US dollar.

Mr Callow said that while unconventional policy was the only real option for the central bank if it couldn't achieve its mandate with the cash rate alone, the Reserve Bank would not be rushed into anything.

"It's untested in Australia and it's a bit of a sign of desperation," he concluded.
description: The Reserve Bank got the currency reaction it wanted after its third rate cut this year, sending the Australian dollar to a 10-year low.
